channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-7679] implement store file management for stripe compactions
item.description: Needs loving. Moving out for now. Can pull in on point release after goes into trunk.
item.summary: implement store file management for stripe compactions

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: I am doing this on top of HBASE-7603 for now.

Attaching the patch based on 7667.

NOTE: this is an example patch that was requested in HBASE-7603, not a real patch. Config class is not related, refactoring of HStore is in HBASE-6703, and I might clean up some things and add logging.

There's lots of unit tests that pass on my machine. This class probably ended up a little more standalone than needed, it makes no assumptions... also there's a config class that as it turns out won't be needed until the policy is implemented. I will remove it into separate JIRA.
forgot to unleash qa...

can you put it on review board, with HBASE-7603 as parent? at least is easy to comment and see what are the changes from HBASE-7603.

Do you have a public github branch with all this store+compaction refactor?

Posted preliminary review in https://reviews.apache.org/r/9338/
I think that refactor should into trunk (otherwise it will depend on complete implementation of policies, which will cause a lot of churn for no benefit; especially given the release cutting for 96 it can get stuck there for months).
For this JIRA there may be separate branch later, although I am not sure it makes sense. Tiered compaction is already targeted for trunk; this is not a much bigger feature, just 2 JIRAs now by itself. Anyway for now by itself this JIRA is not very valuable.
rebase

minor test issue, due to allowing the start stripe to start anywhere now when first stripe is invalid the first key is not guaranteed to be chosen as open-key, so the set of files test provides depends on order, changed it. I will attach the patch tomorrow cause I have to run now.
patch ready

Ping? Matteo Bertozzi stack what do you guys think about how this should go in?

All patches (HBASE-7679 HBASE-7680 HBASE-7967 HBASE-8000) together, or separately? My plan was to commit separately to trunk only for now

Separate if possible; too hard for little minds like mind keeping it all in my head. Let me get you a review....

ConcatenatedLists should have unit test.

Should this define be in the Interface or do you think it implementation specific?

+ public static final String BLOCKING_STOREFILES_KEY = "hbase.hstore.blockingStoreFiles";

This has to be public?

+ public byte[] getMetadataValue(byte[] key) {

On StripeStoreFileManager, do we know if this approach has merit? Have we run models or actual test runs and can see it saves i/o? Would be interesting to know. Do we have to commit it to figure this out? I can see committing all the refactorings which allow different compaction policies but would think a compaction engine would need to have proven merit before it goes in? What you think Sergey?

Do we have to have a L0? Can we not flush multiple files when we flush, one per boundary in the region? Was that thought just too much work flushing?

ConcatenatedLists should have unit test.

Added.

Should this define be in the Interface or do you think it implementation specific?

+ public static final String BLOCKING_STOREFILES_KEY = "hbase.hstore.blockingStoreFiles";

Not certain, having things in HStore seems to be the convention. Store isn't a "real" interface that invites different implementation

On StripeStoreFileManager, do we know if this approach has merit? Have we run models or actual test runs and can see it saves i/o? Would be interesting to know. Do we have to commit it to figure this out? I can see committing all the refactorings which allow different compaction policies but would think a compaction engine would need to have proven merit before it goes in? What you think Sergey?

I have an integration test in HBASE-8000, but have only run it for correctness now.
I plan to make a bigger test for perf, and move to commit after having some numbers.

Do we have to have a L0? Can we not flush multiple files when we flush, one per boundary in the region? Was that thought just too much work flushing?

I was concerned about many small files, and scope creep into memstore, as discussed.
Let me do a write-up on this (probably useful anyway), and discuss on dev list.
After integration tests on tiny files (not a target scenario for this, but still), I wonder if impact of L0 files on # of files to be read for gets is indeed worth it.
On the other hand for scans, and for overall situation large number of small files is not good.
updated patch

Agree lets get numbers before saying L0 is bad. Ditto get numbers before commit and yes a write up would be helpful. Smarter compaction could make for big wins all around Sergey. Thanks for persisting.

This message is automatically generated.
You put the strip boundary in each store file. Why is that? It will make it hard to change the stripes dynamically, right?

It makes it impossible to change it dynamically, which is not necessary for currently envisioned operations, other than small optimizations.
It makes loading/adding files much simpler/more reliable though. Added to future improvements in the doc in parent JIRA.
Updating with r feedback

Did above ever happen Sergey Shelukhin? Thanks.

Yes, I did some testing with real random reads for HBaseCon slides, with yet-unpublished patch about L0.
Latest round (8 writer threads, 3 updater threads, 1 deleter thread deleting no more than 5% of data, some verifiers and 8 random read threads):

the stripes test takes less time, at least; there's also benefits to the latency variability; I will mention it during HBaseCon talk. Basically it seems to be viable and provides improvement for large regions. There's also some, older, perf testing in the parent jira
